title: Marathi Christians
text:
Marathi Christians are an <a href="Ethnoreligious%20group">Ethno-religious community</a> of the <a href="States%20and%20territories%20of%20India">Indian state</a> of <a href="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a> who were <a href="Evangelism">evangelised</a> during the 18th and 19th centuries during the <a href="East%20India%20Company">East India Company</a>, and later, the <a href="British%20Raj">British Raj</a>. Conversions to <a href="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> were a result of <a href="Mission%20%28Christianity%29">Christian missions</a> such as the American Marathi Mission, <a href="Church%20Mission%20Society">Church Mission Society</a> and the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>'s <a href="United%20Society%20for%20the%20Propagation%20of%20the%20Gospel">United Society for the Propagation of the Gospel</a>.
History.
Around the turn of the 18th century, <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="Baptists">Baptist</a> <a href="missionary">missionary</a> <a href="William%20Carey%20%28missionary%29">William Carey</a> was instrumental in translating the <a href="Bible">Bible</a> into the <a href="Marathi%20language">Marathi language</a>. Most of the converts were lower-caste <a href="Hindus">Hindus</a> with some upper-caste Hindus and <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>.
Ahmednagar.
The <a href="American%20Board%20of%20Commissioners%20for%20Foreign%20Missions">American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions</a> established their first foreign mission with the American Marathi mission in <a href="Mumbai">Bombay</a> in 21 December 1813, it was the first <a href="List%20of%20Protestant%20missionary%20societies">Protestant Mission</a> in <a href="Western%20India">Western India</a> and spread into hundreds of villages. The mission center moved from Bombay to <a href="Ahmednagar%20district">Ahmednagar</a> in 1831 because it was closer to the center of marathi country. School, Boardings, Colleges and theological institutions were created by Marathi mission in late 1800, aiding famine and reaching untouchables increased Christian Converts in area. 
Christians of <a href="Ahmednagar%20district">Ahmednagar district</a> account for nearly 10% of district's population, a significant number of whom are located in the eastern part of the district in places such as <a href="Nevasa">Nevasa</a>, <a href="Pathardi">Pathardi</a>, <a href="Shevgaon">Shevgaon</a>, <a href="Rahuri">Rahuri</a> and <a href="Ahmednagar">Ahmednagar</a> itself.
Palghar.
European and American missionaries established missions in <a href="Palghar">Palghar</a> and <a href="Dahanu">Dahanu</a> in <a href="Palghar%20district">Palghar district</a>. Most of the converted Christian community from these areas are local native belong to the Second District of the Church of the Brethren (F-257 Bom).
Aurangabad.
Aurangabad is head city for Catholics as it has its Cathedral and Bishop house in Cantonment area work is monitored of whole of Marathwada mainly in field of Educational, health, and social work
Yavatmal.
The American Free Methodist Church maintains missions at <a href="Yavatmal">Yavatmal</a>, <a href="Wani%2C%20Maharashtra">Wani</a>, <a href="Umri%2C%20Nanded">Umri</a>, <a href="Rajur">Rajur</a> and Darwah.
Culture.
There are similarities of customs and culture between Hindus and Marathi Christians, such as dress, food and cuisine. The Hindu custom of wearing <a href="Saree">Saree</a>, <a href="Mangalsutra">Mangalsutra</a> and placing <a href="Bindi%20%28decoration%29">Bindis</a> is still prominent among native Christians. Marathi Christian highly retain their Marathi culture, and they have kept their Pre-Christian surnames. In Maharashtra, great Marathi poet <a href="Narayan%20Wamanrao%20Tilak">Narayan Wamanrao Tilak</a> realised that a Hindu-Christian synthesis was simply not possible, unless the Christian religion had deep roots in the Indian culture. He trained the Marathi Christians to worship and sing <a href="Bhajan">Bhajan</a> and <a href="Kirtan">Kirtan</a>. He showed Christian faith in a genuinely Indian way.
